summary: On June 11, 2019, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York entered a final judgment against the Ohio State Attorney General's Office for the Northern District of Ohio against Melvin Shirley Jr. and Marcheyell Whitehead for violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Jackson, Mississippi, alleges that the Ohio Attorney General improperly appointed Shirley as a custodial parent for Paisley, despite the fact that Whitehead and Whitehead were not married or dating at the time.  According to the complaint, Whitehead was a good and attentive mother who spent as much time with her child.  Whitehead's mother, Eva Whitehead, testified that she had been with Whitehead her entire life, and that she was reluctant to separate him from her half-brother.  In her opinion and final judgment, the court found that Shirley violated Section 10 of the Exchange Act by failing to adequately consider the issues raised in the complaint.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's findings, Shirley consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins her from future violations of the federal securities laws, orders her to pay a civil penalty of $10,000, and bars her from serving as an officer or director of a public company for five years.  Shirley also agreed to a five-year officer-director bar and to be barred from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any securities in connection with the issuance of the order.  On June 13, 2020, the SEC filed a civil injunctive action against Shirley, charging her with violations of Section 17(a)(1) and (3) of The Securities Act of 1933, and seeks permanent injunctions, disgorgement of ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, and civil penalties against Whitehead.   The case was investigated by the Office of Inspector General (OIG) and the Ohio Department of Health and Human Services, and the case was supervised by C.J. Kerstetter, Chief of the OIG's Division of Child and Family Education.  An SEC examination that led to the investigation was conducted by David J. Blakely and supervised by Jennifer C. McKinley of the Atlanta Regional Office. The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Ohio Secretary of State's Office, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Department of Justice, the Internal Revenue Service, the FBI, the United States Attorney's Office of the Southern Division, the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, the
